prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 3mm observations
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose to observe NGC5044 24 times over the space of 12 months during this cycle to study the very complex spectral and intensity variation that this source exhibits

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We do not expect any absorption or emission features at these standard frequencies.

The source is unresolved at these frequencies so the array configuration makes no difference to the observations and self-calibration will help preserve the phase stability in all but the worst conditions in the most extended configurations.

We request a reasonable margin of sensitivity to ensure that we can detect the source if it were to fade by a factor of 10. Also 2-3 minute observations are the minimum to justify the calibration overheads incured.

Our main requirement for this project is to have close to simultaneous observations in Bands 3, 4 and 6 once a month. This will allow us to sample the variability of this extraordinary spectral component in NGC5044 and contrain if it is generated by an ADAF or jet.
We also request daily observations in a two week block at one point through the Cycle so the shorter timescales can be sampled which relate to the expected light-travel size of the Black Hole.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We do not expect any absorption or emission features at these standard frequencies.

The source is unresolved at these frequencies so the array configuration makes no difference to the observations and self-calibration will help preserve the phase stability in all but the worst conditions in the most extended configurations.

We request a reasonable margin of sensitivity to ensure that we can detect the source if it were to fade by a factor of 10. Also 2-3 minute observations are the minimum to justify the calibration overheads incured.

Our main requirement for this project is to have close to simultaneous observations in Bands 3, 4 and 6 once a month. This will allow us to sample the variability of this extraordinary spectral component in NGC5044 and contrain if it is generated by an ADAF or jet.
We also request daily observations in a two week block at one point through the Cycle so the shorter timescales can be sampled which relate to the expected light-travel size of the Black Hole.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 1mm observations
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose to observe NGC5044 12 times at 230GHz over the space of 12 months during this cycle to study the very complex spectral and intensity variation that this source exhibits. The requested observations include one spectral line passband that covers the CO(2-1) line in this object that is known to show a strong absorption feature in from ALMA Cycle 0 observations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We tune specifically for the CO(2-1) line in this SB to ensure we monitor the depth of the CO(2-1) absorption already known in this source.

The source is unresolved at these frequencies so the array configuration makes no difference to the observations and self-calibration will help preserve the phase stability in all but the worst conditions in the most extended configurations.

We request a reasonable margin of sensitivity to ensure that we can detect the source if it were to fade by a factor of 10. Also we request sufficient S/N to detect the CO(2-1) absorption found in Cycle 0 data so a 15min observation is requested (i.e. comparable to the calibration overheads).

Our main requirement for this project is to have close to simultaneous observations in Bands 3, 4 and 6 once a month. This will allow us to sample the variability of this extraordinary spectral component in NGC5044 and contrain if it is generated by an ADAF or jet.
We require only to constrain the total fraction of polarised flux from the source so no special correlator settings are required.
The angular resolution of these observations is not a factor as the source is very much smaller than the scales reachable by ALMA.
We request the standard continuum mode for these polarisation observations given these are by definition very challenging.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: In Cycle 0 observations of the central galaxy in the brightest X-ray group, NGC5044, we discovered an unexpectedly bright point source at 230GHz at its core. The radio spectrum of this source is highly inverted and resembles the properties of SgrA* in the sub-mm. We have been monitoring this source at 90, 150, 230 and 345GHz with PdBI and JCMT over the past year and it shows large amplitude variability on timescales of weeks. We propose to monitor this source monthly over the next year at 90, 140 and 230GHz with a two week campaign of daily observations at 90 and 140GHz to search for shorter timescale variation in July or August 2016 when it is a day time target. Our 230GHz observations will cover the CO(2-1) line that was detected in absorption in the Cycle 0 data. We also request a single polarisation observation at 230GHz to constrain the origin of the emission in an Advection Dominated Accretion Flow or beamed jet.
